Award.AwardTitle: EXP: Collaborative Research: Engaging Interdisciplinary Students in Innovation Education through Crowd-based Technology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project team is exploring how crowd-based technology can support innovation education through feedback from potential customers and users, specifically looking at how the new forms of authentic feedback can be put to good use to support learning better to design, solve problems, and innovate. Research is around issues in learning through collaborations with potential consumers mediated by technology. What are the affordances of crowd-based technology that can support learning to design, learning to innovate, learning to use feedback well, and learning to effectively iterate towards an effective and innovative result? How does use of such technology and interactions need to be scaffolded to such learning? What crowd-based activities and what types of design challenges afford such learning? Foundations are in Learning by Design (LBD), thick authenticity, and Project-Based Science (PBS).

A key to America's economic and social prosperity depends on people's ability to innovate social and technical solutions. Crowd-based technologies provide opportunities for innovators to interact with potential consumers and experts while innovating, but they have not been used in innovation education. Feedback from crowds could, however, be used to provide learners an opportunity to receive rich informative feedback on design ideas and to develop solutions that fit real-world needs. This project will contribute to our nation's ability to better prepare engineers for innovation. The technology suggested here will, if successful, make opportunities for experiencing both the difficulties of innovating and the kinds of support structures that can help and will provide an infrastructure for helping potential innovators learn to use feedback from others wisely. In addition, the results of this project will contribute towards enhancing project-based experiences throughout the curriculum. What is learned in this project about supporting learning to design, learning to innovate, learning to use feedback well, and learning to effectively iterate towards an effective result has potential to inform the effective use of project-based and design-based classes across grades and disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Industry relies on higher education to prepare students for careers in innovation. Fulfilling this obligation is especially difficult in classroom settings, which often lack authentic interaction with the outside world. Crowd technologies have the potential to change this. Our research explored how scalable, diverse, and accessible online crowds might serve the function of external feedback. Knowing how online crowds might serve the function of external feedback allows us to amplify resources to make innovation education possible.

The intellectual goal of this project was to empirically understand which characteristics of crowd-based platforms that support high quality feedback in project-based innovation courses and to develop design principles and patterns for integrating crowd-based platforms into project-based learning environments - directly contributing to a number of cyberlearning research areas including project based learning, feedback exchange, and online learning communities.

Specifically, the research offers 1) deeper empirical understanding of the relationship between the source of a feedback provider (peers, social media, MTurk, online community, and face to face) and the quantity, quality, content, and responsiveness to the feedback received on design projects; 2) guidance for instructors on how to better orchestrate feedback from different sources to benefit learning and improve project quality, which could also help professional designers consider the tradeoffs in obtaining feedback from colleagues or external crowds; 3) design implications to improve the effectiveness of crowd-based platforms for feedback exchange and 4) new tools and methods for overcoming some of the limitations of crowd-based platforms such as the need for social capital to participate and the need to receive multi-media feedback for different types of design artifacts (storyboards, visual dashboards, written pitches, logo designs).

Based on this empirically driven framework and tools, we developed and refined our "crowd-enhanced" teaching modules for interdisciplinary project-based design courses, which we tested in courses on human-centered design at Northwestern, Carnegie Mellon University, UC San Diego and Design for America’s 36 partner universities. Each student team worked on self-selected real world design challenges. Topics explored by students included on-demand depression therapy, health management, and family-centered savings.  We refined lecture material, in-class activities/demonstrations, and homework activities for teaching how to engage the crowd at key decisions making points in project-based learning. Examples include Ideating with a Crowd, Collecting Needfinding Data through Facebook, and Consumer Analysis Through Online Reviews. We developed and maintained a project website, www.crowddriveninnovation.com, to distribute, track downloads, and receive feedback on instructional material and outcomes. Additionally, we designed and published a template for developing “crowd-enhanced” instructional activities to improve their students’ understanding of and ability to leverage social networks and “crowd-based” communities at each stage of the design process.

We distributed the results broadly through numerous publications at top tier peer publication outlets including Computer Supported Cooperative Work, Design of Interactive Systems, Computer Human Interaction, Crowdsourcing and Human Computation, and Venture well. The project team won additional NSF awards as part of this work as well as numerous teaching awards for introducing new methodologies into the classroom. The project provided opportunities for multiple undergraduate and graduate students to gain experience in learning sciences and human-computer interaction research. It also provided opportunities for PhD students to further develop research skills and mentor and teach more junior team members.

The broader impact goal of this project was to create crowd-based technologies for designers who will tackle our greatest societal challenges.  The technologies were distributed to over 3000 designers who tackled over 300 challenges to advance the national health, prosperity, and welfare.
